headline: Halliburton Cuts Jobs as Oil Prices & Demand Pressure Industry
summary: HAL trims workforce as oil price volatility and weaker demand hit profits, reflecting broader challenges in the oilfield services market.

headline: Analysis-Cuts to US oil jobs and spending threaten output growth
summary: HOUSTON (Reuters) -The U.S. oil industry has laid off thousands of workers and cut billions in spending due to lower oil prices and the biggest consolidation in a generation, in what could mark the end of the rapid output growth that made the U.S. the world's top producer.  The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies in the OPEC+ producer group are increasing output to win back market share that was lost to the United States and other producers in recent years.  Those increases have driven international oil prices down around 12% this year to just above breakeven levels for many U.S. oil companies, prompting cuts in spending and jobs that industry officials say could curb production.

Those increases have driven international oil prices down around 12% this year to just above breakeven levels for many U.S. oil companies, prompting cuts in spending and jobs that industry officials say could curb production.

headline: A Look at Halliburton’s (HAL) Valuation Following Major Layoffs and Industry Headwinds
summary: Halliburton (HAL) is making waves after announcing layoffs that will impact between 20% and 40% of employees across several divisions. The move comes as the company responds to rising costs, declining oil prices, and a noticeable cooldown in industry activity. For investors, such a significant restructuring is a signal that management is focused on staying agile in what has quickly become a more challenging landscape for oilfield service providers. Despite a tough year that has seen the stock...

headline: Aquafortus and Sunchem Join Halliburton Labs as Newest Participants
summary: HOUSTON, September 08, 2025--Halliburton Labs welcomes two innovative startups to its collaborative ecosystem, Aquafortus and Sunchem, each selected for their high-potential technologies to accelerate The future of energy. Faster.™
